list_definition.definition: to be in or fill (time, space etc)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: A table occupied the centre of the room.
The family occupied a small flat.

list_ex_of_english: Sheiling settlements, which would have been occupied in the summer months, survive extensively due to their now marginal location.
Frequently former chiefs occupied posts in the new hierarchies of popular power or the latter co-existed with royal rule by other means.
The third is stopped, occupying the upper area of the common workspace and constitutes a static obstacle.
The lead paper in this short book occupies roughly one-third of the total: the remainder consists of commentaries.
Classes often start late and are shorter than the scheduled hours, and quite frequently, because their teachers are otherwise occupied, classes are postponed or cancelled.
Any part of the soil surface that is not occupied by crop species is potentially subject to invasion by weedy species.
In this approach mathematical pattern occupies the first place.
The area occupied by damaged cells did not exceed 10% of the total surface area occupied by axis cells.
